question: Why do you believe you killed your parents?
answer: Well, that's a good question, Piers.

question: Do you remember watching "The Matrix" repeatedly, watching these video games and the kind of effect it had on you?
answer: When I would watch "The Matrix," I would see myself in that role.

question: Do you believe now that that was the case?
answer: Well, to put it bluntly, I -- I know that there's something wrong with me in -- in my head.

question: How much was that playing on your mind, do you think, through this period leading up to what you did?
answer: It impacted me a lot.

question: Do you remember where you got the gun and were you subjected to any kind of background check?
answer: Yes, I do remember.

question: And what was your intention, when you purchased the gun, to murder your parents?
answer: Actually, it wasn't.

question: But did your adopted parents, do you think, have any real idea of what you were going through in your head?
answer: They didn't know, really, what was going on.

question: They never mistreated you, your adopted parents?
answer: Well, no, my adopted parents, my father was -- he wasn't like that with me, but my mother, she would beat my sister and I a lot.

question: What was going through your head as you heard that music?
answer: Well, I -- I had been listening to the song for about a year nonstop.

question: But again, as with the violent video games, do you think that violent musical, video and music can have a -- a profound and disturbing effect on people who may themselves be mentally unstable?
answer: I believe so, especially on the young mind.

question: And what then happened?
answer: That's a good question.

question: As you were doing that, what was the sensation that you were experiencing?
answer: Actually, I had no emotion at all.

question: Even at the moment that you'd realized you'd murdered both your parents, was there any kind of reality check or did you still believe that this was some weird, horrible, violent videogame that you were possibly enacting for real?
answer: Well, the things that went on that night, it really reminded me -- it did remind me of "The Matrix."

question: What do you say to those people?
answer: Well, I would say that, whenever I talk to anyone about this, I always tell them that I don't blame anyone but myself.

question: But do you think the system, the mental health system in America should have picked you up earlier?
answer: Yes, absolutely, I agree.

question: When you've seen the mass shootings at places like Aurora, in the movie theater with James Holmes, and also with Adam Lanza at Sandy Hook -- do you recognize, from everything that you've read about these two shooters, similarities in the way that, perhaps, you were thinking at the time that you committed your atrocity?
answer: OOKE: Absolutely.

question: Do you think that the easy availability of guns is also a big problem in America for disturbed young men in particular, like yourselves?
answer: Absolutely.

question: If you had the chance to speak to them again -- which you never will -- but if you did have the chance, what would you say to them?
answer: Well, first, I actually do believe that I will see them again.

question: Are you -- are you now receiving any kind of treatment or medication for any mental health issues?
answer: No, I'm not.

question: What did you make of it?
answer: I thought he was extremely candid with you.

question: How much of that is a problem with these shootings, where unstable young people, who perhaps are disenfranchised from society, want to make a stir for themselves, get in the headlines, become infamous?
answer: Well, 99.9 percent of those who watch the news about Columbine or another shooting identify with the pain and the suffering of the victims, and pray every day that a Columbine will not happen in their school.

question: You can do it without being mentally unstable?
answer: I get asked that question on the stand all the time in death penalty cases by prosecutors when I'm working for the defense.

question: And what was he doing with all of his time, watching video games?
answer: Yes.

question: You agree with that?
answer: Yes, I think here, the video game playing is a symptom, not a cause.

question: What do you think of the gun aspect of this?
answer: I believe him.

question: Do you believe that they can just grow out of this, even if they have a condition like schizophrenia?
answer: Well, to some extent, we do know that people are at the violent peak when late adolescence, early adulthood.

question: Did you believe him?
answer: Yes.

question: James Fox?
answer: About some things yes, some things no.

question: Cheryl Olson?
answer: I think -- as -- he said it the way he sees it.

question: How's it going?
answer: Good.

question: Are you getting excited for classes?
answer: Oh, yes.

question: I'm so proud of you, you know?
answer: Our mentorship program matches refugee girls from high school with mentors who work with them during the week.

question: You have to write an essay, right?
answer: Yes, I want to write about my life.
